paragraphs.text: Design Thinking became first relevant in a time when designing products was predominantly driven by business and tech rationales. The human was seen as consumer or user (don’t be fooled — there is a predominant technocratic notion to the term “user”). The design discipline and its focus on the human was still nascent and in permanent need of fighting for consideration in terms of its relevance, its inclusion in processes, and (above all) resources.

Experience metrics are an essential component of product KPIs together with business and technical metrics. The design discipline needs to have a strong mandate to establish experience metrics to be able to assess the quality of the product experience for humans.
paragraphs.name: a28e

paragraphs.text: Interdisciplinarity at the core of product teams means for design teams to work within product verticals. Design teams that become too isolated, can face the danger of “dissolving” inside the product vertical. The continuous exposure to business and tech rationales can cause design teams to soften their focus on the human as their core competency.
paragraphs.name: b351

paragraphs.text: The challenge Design Thinking faces in practice is that it is perceived as too disconnected from business because of its general misperception and its uncredited impact.

Design advocates the human by understanding human needs and articulates the relationship of humans with products. Products are tools and services that are part of a human ecosystem of tasks and much deeper — almost spiritual — human drivers. Products empower humans and enhance human abilities. In that sense, products are extensions of the human. Design is the discipline responsible for exploring human challenges and developing solutions that — in a broader view — help expand humanity itself.
paragraphs.name: c9d7

paragraphs.text: Design methodologies are undoubtably part of Design Thinking, but they are not one and the same thing. Design Thinking is broader and more holistic and is not limited to live within the design discipline alone. While the design discipline is a main driver for Design Thinking, it does not own it.
paragraphs.name: 683e

paragraphs.text: The business, tech, and design disciplines naturally have distinct perspectives on the human and approaches to problem solving. Business would like to see a product generate crazy amounts of money, tech wants it to function flawlessly, while the design discipline wants to create a product that is so desirable that people lose their minds over it.
paragraphs.name: 408f

paragraphs.text: Design Thinking is being widely misunderstood. It is often associated exclusively with the design discipline or seen as a creativity tool that involves an enormous amount of post-its. Many mistake Design Thinking for design methodologies or the design process itself.
paragraphs.name: 954f

5ce735b4c029.title: How Design Thinking will fix Design Thinking

paragraphs.text: How Design Thinking will fix Design Thinking
paragraphs.name: d36d

paragraphs.text: Design Thinking continues to be a hot topic (this article is one of many talking about it). Design Thinking has been hyped and even fetishized but there are also voices questioning its value, impact, and relevance. Design Thinking faces criticism for…
paragraphs.name: a434

content.metaDescription: Design Thinking faces criticism for its lacking integration with business and compatibility with market reality. Does Design Thinking have to be reinvented or even replaced? Here is why not.

virtuals.metaDescription: Design Thinking faces criticism for its lacking integration with business and compatibility with market reality. Does Design Thinking have to be reinvented or even replaced? Here is why not.

paragraphs.text: Yes, indeed.
paragraphs.name: 38f8

paragraphs.text: It’s hard to “locate” Design Thinking and associate it with one place (e.g. the intersections alone). DT is in a way transcendent and stretches across the entire organization. And yes, the dynamics of DT are manifesting most strongly at the intersections between disciplines.
paragraphs.name: 47bc

paragraphs.text: This is where journalism is today. That’s why my colleagues at the CUNY Graduate School of Journalism and I are trying to move the conversation in our profession from “What can we do for (and to) the public?” to “What does the public want us to do for (and with) them?”
